awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CSSI: Framework: Data: Clowder Open Source Customizable Research Data Management, Plus-Plus
awd_abstract_narration:
Preserving, sharing, navigating, and reusing large and diverse collections of data is now essential to scientific discoveries in areas such as phenomics, materials science, geoscience, and urban science. These data navigation needs are also important when addressing the growing number of research areas where data and tools must span multiple domains. To support these needs effectively, new methods are required that simplify and reduce the amount of effort needed by researchers to find and utilize data, support community accepted data practices, and bring together the breadth of standards, tools, and resources utilized by a community. Clowder, an active curation based data management system, addresses these needs and challenges by distributing much of the data curation overhead throughout the lifecycle of the data, augmenting this with social curation and automated analysis tools, and providing extensible community-dependent means of viewing and navigating data. As an open source framework, built to be extensible at every level, Clowder is capable of interacting with and utilizing a variety of community tools while also supporting different data governance and ownership requirements.

The project enhances Clowder's core systems for the benefit of a larger group of users. It increases the level of interoperability with community resources, hardens the core software, and distributes core software development, while continuing to expand usage.  Governance mechanisms and a business model are established to make Clowder sustainable, creating an appropriate governance structure to ensure that the software continues to be available, supportable, and usable.  The effort engages a number of stakeholders, taking data from diverse but converging scientific domains already using the Clowder framework, to address broad interoperability and cross domain data sharing. The overall effort will transition the grassroots Clowder user community and Clowder's other stakeholders (such as current and potential developers) into a larger organized community, with a sustainable software resource supporting convergent research data needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Clowder Framework project has made significant progress in helping researchers in the humanities and a variety of scientific disciplines manage and analyze massive amounts of data generated by research, particularly in the field of plant science for this project. Understanding how plants respond to their environment is a fundamental aspect of plant science research, breeding new crop varieties, and agricultural production of food, fuel, and fiber. Phenotyping is the process of measuring plant responses to the environment and it is a major bottleneck in scientific and agricultural work. However, imaging and sensor technologies are transforming our ability to measure plants at larger scales and higher frequency, which enables advances in research, breeding, crop production, and agricultural sustainability efforts. The Clowder Framework enables utilization of these phenotyping technologies through active data management and automation. Our project developed methods for measuring plant phenotypes from image data and managing results within the Clowder Framework.

 

We developed methods to utilize Clowder to ingest data from automated plant imaging systems and connected Clowder to other open-source frameworks such as PlantCV to develop automated image analysis processes that measured plant phenotypes as data was collected. We also developed data analysis, modeling, and visualization tools to provide researchers with insights to their data while experiments were running, which allowed for real-time decision making. Results from the experiments analyzed through this process have contributed to insights into both research plant systems and agricultural crops.

The broader impact of our work extends beyond plant science. By making all of our software open-source and freely available, we have created resources that other researchers, companies, or other interested parties can use and adapt for their specific needs. These tools also contribute to making science more open and reproducible. A key achievement has been making complex data analysis more accessible to researchers who are not computer programming experts. This has helped bridge the gap between collecting data and gaining useful insights from it, accelerating the pace of scientific discovery.

We developed these tools and methods with long-term sustainability in mind and they will continue to evolve and find new applications. Our project has demonstrated how modern software development approaches can help solve real-world research challenges and make scientific work more efficient, accessible, and reproducible.

 


Last Modified: 01/06/2025
Modified by: Noah Fahlgren
